Package tage.rml

Class Quaternionf

java.lang.Object
tage.rml.Quaternionf
All Implemented Interfaces:
Comparable<Quaternion>, Quaternion
public class Quaternionf extends Object implements Quaternion
An immutable single-precision floating point implementation of a quaternion.

The implementation assumes the input arrays have enough elements to build the quaternion. When the input array does not have enough elements, an IndexOutOfBoundsException will be thrown. However, when the input array has extra elements, the extra data are ignored.

Author:
Raymond L. Rivera

    • createFrom

      public static Quaternion createFrom(float[] values)
      Creates a new quaternion from the specified (w, [x, y, z]) values, where w is the scalar part and [x, y, z] is the vector part.

      If the scalar w component is outside the [-1, 1] range, it will be automatically clamped.

      Parameters:
      values - The (w, [x, y, z]) components of the quaternion.
      Returns:
      A new quaternion with the specified values.
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException - If the input array has less than 4 elements.

    • createFrom

      public static Quaternion createFrom(float w, float x, float y, float z)
      Creates a new quaternion from the specified (w, [x, y, z]) values, where w is the scalar part and [x, y, z] is the vector part.
      Parameters:
      w - The value for the scalar part. If it's outside the [-1, 1] range, it's automatically clamped.
      x - The x component of the vector part.
      y - The y component of the vector part.
      z - The z component of the vector part.
      Returns:
      A new quaternion with the specified values.

      Returns:

    • mult

      public Quaternion mult(Quaternion q)
      Returns a new quaternion with the product of this quaternion post-multiplied by the specified quaternion. Note also that the returned quaternion is not necessarily a unit quaternion and may need to be normalized (e.g. if at least one of the two quaternions being multiplied is not unit-length).

      Quaternion multiplication can be used to compose rotations, similar to matrix concatenation. The product of two quaternions p and q is defined as follows: 

       p = (w1, v1), where v1 = [x1, y1, z1]
 q = (w2, v2), where v2 = [x2, y2, z2]

 pq = (w1 * w2 - (v1 . v2), [v2 * w1 + v1 * w2 + (v1 x v2)])
      where w represents the scalar part and v represents the vector part.
      Parameters:
      q - The quaternion to be post-multiplied with this quaternion
      Returns:
      A new quaternion p' = pq

    • mult

      public Quaternion mult(float s)
      Returns a new quaternion with the result of multiplying (scaling) this quaternion by the specified scalar value.

      The definition of multiplying a quaternion by a scalar value is that it produces a new quaternion where each component of the original has been multiplied by the scalar value. Note also that the returned quaternion is not necessarily a unit quaternion and may need to be normalized.

      Parameters:
      s - The value to be multiplied by each component of this quaternion.
      Returns:
      A new quaternion with the result of this multiplication.

    • dot

      public float dot(Quaternion q)

    • inverse

      public Quaternion inverse()
      Returns a new quaternion that is the inverse of this one.

      The inverse quaternion q" is defined as: 

       q' = q* / ||q||^2
      where q* is the conjugate and ||q|| is the length of this instance.

    • conjugate

      public Quaternion conjugate()
      Description copied from interface: Quaternion
      Returns the conjugate of this quaternion as a new quaternion.

      The conjugate q' of a quaternion q = (w, [x, y, z]) is defined as: 

       q' = (w, [-x, -y, -z])
      Specified by:
      conjugate in interface Quaternion
      Returns:
      A new quaternion that is the conjugate of this quaternion.

    • lerp

      public Quaternion lerp(Quaternion end, float t)

    • slerp

      public Quaternion slerp(Quaternion end, float t)

      Quaternion slerp between p and q by t is defined as: 

       slerp(p, q, t) = p*lambda + q*phi | t in [0, 1]
      where: 
       lambda = sin(theta*[1 - t]) / sin(theta)
 phi    = sin(theta*t) / sin(theta)
 theta  = acos(p . q)
      There're some edge-cases the implementation accounts for:
      • returns this iff t == 0.0
      • returns end iff t == 1.0
      • uses lerp(Quaternion, float) if this and end are very close, i.e. cos(theta) ~ +1
      • uses lerp(Quaternion, float) as fallback if this and end are almost opposite, i.e., cos(theta) ~ -1
      The last lerp(Quaternion, float) fallback case is necessary due to an infinite number of possible interpolation paths along the great arc without a reliable way to choose the correct one.

      For more details, see:

      • Game Engine Architecture, 2nd Ed, p.208;
      • Understanding Quaternions; and
      • Quaternion::Slerp(float, Quaternion, Quaternion, bool) from OGRE3D
